summary: On June 26, 2019, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New Mexico entered a final judgment against William Serna, a convicted felon in possession of a firearm in connection with another felony drug possession offense.  The court granted the SEC's request for a temporary restraining order and an asset freeze, as well as other emergency relief.  According to the court's order, filed in federal court in Albuquerque, N.M. on May 29, 2019 (D.N.M., Jan. 12, 2019) that granted the Court's motion for a preliminary injunction, entered a default judgment, and entered an order suspending the asset freeze pending final judgment.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for New Mexico today announced criminal charges against the defendant for his role in a drug-trafficking scheme.   The SEC's complaint alleges that, in a hand-to-hand transaction that resembled a narcotics transaction, the defendant was likely emboldened to possess his methamphetamine and could protect himself and his drug supply.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, the court also issued an order freezing the assets of the defendant and ordering him to pay a civil penalty of $1,000,000. Â The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted in the Denver Regional Office and the case is being supervised by Kelly L. Gibson. The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the New Mexico Department of Justice, the Albuquerque Police Department, and the FBI in this matter.  For further information, see Press Release No. 13-20-2019, June 27, 2019.Â On July 12, 2020, the SEC filed a complaint in the United Kingdom Court of Appeals for the Central and Southern Districts of New York, alleging that the defendants violated the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act") and Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and seeks a permanent injunction, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, and civil penalties.  Separately, the Court issued an Order suspending the purchase, sale, and registration of a.22-caliber handgun and a.38-caliber rifle, and ordering the forfeiture of all of the defendants' allegedly illegal assets.  On July 13, 2020 the Court granted the court’s request for an emergency asset freeze and ordered the seizure and destruction of any evidence that may be relevant to the alleged drug trafficking activity. The court also ordered the destruction of all evidence in the case, including any evidence of a prior felony drug trafficking conviction, to be deemed satisfied by the court
